intro: ig I have a recipe site now ü§†Ô∏è these cookies slap but read the tips to make even better ones üß† recipe is my own but inspired by Nick Digiovanni's choco chip cookie and Benjamin the Baker's thick and gooey choco chip cookies
subtitle: 450-500 cal per cookie
ingredientsTip: There are lots of tutorials online on how to toast milk powder! This is an optional ingredient but I promise it's 100% worth it!
ingredientsInfo: Mix-ins are marked with (*). These are honestly up to your discretion but I would keep the total mix-ins around 25-30% of your dough's volume
tools: parchment paper or silicone baking mats
toolsTip: A stand mixer will make your life so much easier for the creaming process. also PLEASE use a scale!

steps.description: Start with your dry ingredients! mix the all-purpose flour, bread flour, baking powder, baking soda, and salt together in a large bowl
steps.tip: I recommend using a whisk to mix and also sifting the flour but honestly not mandatory if you're lazy

steps.description: Chop up your desired amount of baker's chocolate, break your graham crackers and marshmallows into small pieces, and combine them in a separate bowl with your chocolate chips
steps.tip: The more mix-ins you add, the less your dough will spread, leading to a thicker cookie. I also don't like adding marshmallows directly into the mix-ins, they melt unpredictably and the sugar can burn but in turn it creates some tasty caramelized sections so up to you

steps.description: In another large bowl, with either the stand mixer or a hand mixer, cream together the softened butter, granulated sugar, brown sugar, and toasted milk powder until light and fluffy (about 7-9 minutes on medium speed). The final creamed mixture should have increased 2 to 2.5x in volume
steps.info: Be sure to scrape the sides of the bowl periodically to ensure an even mix!

steps.description: Add in each egg one by one on medium speed. Be sure that the first egg is fully mixed in before adding the second. Also add in the vanilla extract alongside the first egg
Add in your dry ingredients on low speed and mix until no flour streaks are visible. Afterwards add the mix-ins and mix on low speed
steps.info: Be sure to not overmix and remember to periodically scrape the sides to ensure an even mix!
steps.tip: Add a towel on top of your stand mixer when first mixing your dry ingredients to prevent the flour from getting everywhere

steps.description: Scoop the dough using a cookie scoop (or just your hands lol). Be sure that each scoop weighs 110 grams and wrap a normal-sized marshmallow (or a bunch of small ones squished together) into the center of the dough and form a ball. Place the dough balls on parchment paper and set in the fridge for at least 24 hours
steps.tip: I actually like using my hands cause the uneven edges crisp up nicely when baked but up to personal preference
steps.info: If you're impatient, you can bake it even after 1 hr in the fridge. But TRUST me, you want to wait the 24 hours to let the flour develop there is a massive difference

steps.description: Preheat your oven to 360¬∞F. Place your cookies on a baking sheet with parchment paper and bake your cookies for 10 mins (or until you see the dough spreading significantly and the bottom is starting to brown a bit). Then lift and drop your baking sheet twice on the oven rack and finish baking for another 2-3 minutes (or until the bottom is a nice golden brown/brown)
steps.info: The pan-banging (lifting and dropping) creates better texture and appearance by deflating the cookies. This is not mandatory but its such an easy step to elevate your end result

steps.description: Remove from oven and let the cookies set, enjoy!
steps.info: The cookies should come out really soft/gooey to the touch. This is normal as the sugars and butter are still melted so don't worry, they will solidify nicely once cooled!

steps.description: Optional: Some variations have a graham cracker on the bottom, I tried that and didn't really like it as the cookie didn't cook as good in the oven. You can also add marshmallows immediately on top after taking the cookies out of the oven.
